Autoridades ucranianas afirmaron este jueves que el ejército de Rusia mantiene por tercer día consecutivo el asalto a la metalúrgica Azovstal, en la ciudad de Mariúpol, mientras el regimiento Azov defiende la planta.

"Ya van tres días de asalto activo en el recinto de la planta Azovstal", indicó el subcomandante del regimiento Azov, Svyatoslav Palamar, que agregó que hay combates y no hay régimen de silencio, es decir, no hay un alto el fuego.

Te puede interesar: Autoridades en Ucrania localizan cadáveres con signos de tortura

En declaraciones a la cadena digital Hromadske recogidas por la agencia Unian, Palamar agregó que no se están evacuando civiles de la planta.

Mundo

Asimismo negó las acusaciones del portavoz del presidente ruso, Vladímir Putin, según las cuales los combatientes ucranianos presuntamente retienen a civiles como rehenes y exigen canjearlos por alimentos y medicinas.

También el jefe de la policía de patrulla de Mariúpol, Mijailo Vershinin, confirmó a Unian que el asalto continúa. "Están atacando el perímetro tanto como pueden y tratan de avanzar", señaló.

El asesor de la presidencia ucraniana, Oleksiy Arestovych, aseguró en televisión que los intensos combates continúan, pero que los defensores ucranianos lograron expulsar a los rusos del recinto.

"Ayer las tropas rusas entraron en el recinto de Azovstal, pero fueron expulsados por nuestros defensores. Ahora estamos recapitulando la información", dijo Arestovich, citado por Unian.

Los medios publicaron ayer informaciones sobre el avance de las tropas rusas en Azovstal que, según Arestovych, deben ser aclaradas.

Un resumen del Estado Mayor de las 18:00 horas señalaba que las tropas rusas estaban intentando sin éxito destruir las unidades ucranianas en la zona de Azovstal.

Rusia sostiene alto al fuego para evacuar

Por su parte, el Kremlin sostuvo que la orden de no asaltar el complejo metalúrgico dada por el presidente Vladimir Putin sigue vigente, y acusó que el regimiento apostado en Azovstal transmite constantemente información falsa.

"La parte ucraniana, especialmente aquellos que se refugian en el territorio de la planta (de Azovstal), son bien conocidos por producir una gran cantidad de mentiras y falsificaciones de manera continua. Por lo tanto, la información que proviene de ellos debe filtrarse de la manera más exhaustiva", dijo el portavoz de la Presidencia rusa, Dmitri Peskov.

Peskov comentó así durante su rueda de prensa diaria las informaciones de Kiev sobre la irrupción de tropas rusas en el territorio de la acería e intensos combates en Azovstal.

El representante del Kremlin insistió en que la orden de suspender el asalto de la acería sigue en pie, aunque subrayó que su bloqueo continúa. "A la vez, estos días funcionarán corredores para la salida de los civiles", dijo Peskov.

El Ministerio de Defensa de Rusia prometió el miércoles abrir hoy y los días 6 y 7 de mayo corredores humanitarios para la evacuación de todos los civiles que se encuentren en Azovstal en la dirección que "ellos elijan", en referencia a zonas controladas por fuerzas rusas o por el Gobierno de Kiev.

Durante la conferencia de prensa, Peskov también comentó informaciones en los medios que hablan de la entrega a Ucrania de datos de inteligencia sobre el movimiento de tropas rusos por parte de Estados Undios , que supuestamente ha llevado al asesinato de varios generales.

"Nuestros militares son muy conscientes de que Estados Unidos, el Reino Unido y la OTAN en su conjunto transmiten constantemente datos de inteligencia y otra información a las fuerzas armadas de Ucrania", dijo Peskov.

A la vez, agregó que eso no impedirá que "los objetivos de la operación militar especial rusa en Ucrania sean cumplidos".

The EU has proposed sanctioning former Russian gymnast Alina Kabaeva for her role in Kremlin propaganda and close ties to Russian President Vladimir Putin, according to a document seen Thursday by AFP.

Kabaeva is a late addition to the list of individuals targeted in a sixth package of measures against Russia in response to the war in Ukraine.

The sanctions, which include a ban on Russian oil imports, were submitted on Wednesday by the EU executive to member states for approval, which requires unanimity among the 27 countries.

Hungary, Slovakia and other eastern European countries are so far refusing the package, holding out for an opt out or delay to the oil ban.

If passed, Kabaeva would be hit by a ban on entry into the EU and an asset freeze.

The proposal identifies Kabaeva as the chairwoman of the board of directors of the National Media Group, a holding company that holds significant shares in almost all major Russian state media.

The former gymnast and former Duma lawmaker is "closely associated with President Vladimir Putin," the document adds.

Media reports claim that she and the Russian president are romantically involved, which Putin denied when the story was first reported in 2008.

According to a report in The Wall Street Journal, citing US officials, Kabaeva and her family have gained personal fortune thanks to her connection to Putin's inner circle.

The report cites classified US intelligence that names Kabaeva as a beneficiary of Putin's wealth.

Three other people, columnists at the state agency Ria Novosti, are also on the list for their role in disseminating "government propaganda" over the war in Ukraine.

The four names are in addition to 58 people -- including the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Kirill, numerous military personnel suspected of war crimes in the Ukrainian town of Butcha and family members of Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov.

Since the annexation of Crimea in 2014, European sanctions have already affected 1,091 people and 80 entities.

articleContent.content: The 2020 Victory Day Parade . . WASHINGTON-As Russia's war against Ukraine progresses, Ukrainians and the West are on edge about the Kremlin's plans for celebrating a key day in Russian history. . . This year, May 9, known as Victory Day for Russians in memory of the triumph over Nazi Germany, could coincide with some key decision by Vladimir Putin: if a month ago it was said that it could mark the end of the invasion, now some believe it could mark the day Russia stops talking about "special operation" and declares war on Ukraine. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov today dismissed that possibility. . . . . Putin, during the 2020 parade . . In late March, the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Ukraine said that Russian soldiers were being told that the war must end by that date. On April 10, Axios reported that that deadline could become a turning point in the war. . . Ukraine's Defense Ministry projected Tuesday that the invasion that began Feb. 24, which Russia has called a "special military operation," may last until September. . . . . Russian Army musicians rehearse for the May 9 parade in St. Petersburg. . . The U.S. State Department, meanwhile, said it would be "a great irony if Moscow were to use the occasion of Victory Day to declare war." . . State Department spokesman Ned Price said the Kremlin's goals - "subjugate Ukraine, increase Russian power, divide the West" - have fallen short of a "strategic failure," which may lead to more propaganda. . . What is commemorated . . While speculation continues, the importance of May 9 for Russians cannot be underestimated, Russian history scholars said. . . Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel, loyal to Adolf Hitler and commander of the German armed forces during World War II, signed the act of military surrender on May 8 in Berlin, although the time difference between Germany and Russia meant it occurred on the 9th for Russia and its neighboring countries. . . . . Images from last year's parade . . That date would go on to be recognized by the USSR and the Soviet bloc. Putin added more pomp to the holiday, and the World War II victory tradition continues to be reflected through Russian media, including film and television. . . May 9 is more than a holiday. It is a day for parades, for veterans to dress up in their military attire, and for Russians to revel in Russian traditions. . . Celebrating the defeat of Nazi Germany is deeply rooted in Russian national identity and has the same level of reverence if not more, than the triumphs of the Sputnik space program, said Stephen Brain, associate professor of Soviet and Russian history. at Mississippi State University. . . "It's the victory of good over evil," , he said. "Maybe you can call them stereotypical because of their toughness and determination, but that's what they demonstrated in that war." . . . . A plane flies over Moscow during the 2021 parade. . . Last year, Russia celebrated May 9 by rolling World War II-era Soviet T-34 tanks through the streets, flying 76 fighter jets and helicopters and displaying a Russian RS-24 ballistic missile on Red Square. . . Putin also used the day's celebration to spread propaganda and throw jabs at the West , denouncing "Russophobia" and vowing that his nation would defend its interests. Russia was already attracting international criticism at the time for beefing up its military presence on the border with Ukraine and for its treatment of Russian opposition figure Alexei Navalny. . . Victory Day is roughly equivalent to the Fourth of July in the United States, but even that comparison doesn't really capture the magnitude of what the day means to Russia and what it means to be Russian, said Brain, who added that the Soviet Union lost 24 million civilians and troops, the highest total number of casualties of any country in World War II. . . Although veterans who fought in the war are dying off over the years, the memory of that war is unlikely to fade, and upcoming holidays will likely come with rhetoric about Nazism and fascism, according to Faith Hillis, a professor of modern Russian and European history at the University of Chicago. . . Anti-Ukrainian sentiments will likely be part of this year's Victory Day, but Russia is hardly in a position to proclaim for a triumph. . . Alexander Vindman, a former infantry officer and director of European affairs at the National Security Council, told Axios that May 9 could mark a turning point for Russia. . . "Russia will not stop in the face of limited advances," said Vindman, who was born in Soviet-era Ukraine. "Protracted war is a recipe for leading, potentially, to a confrontation with NATO." . . Experts say Russia has already lost its propaganda war against Ukraine after the reported atrocities in Bucha and other Ukrainian allegations. But it seems implausible that Putin would relent, the academics said. . . "I think for Putin there will be no defeat, even if there is one," Hillis said. "There is no room for a defeat in his thinking. It's going to be spun as a victory no matter what."

articleSummary.title: Victory Day: what Russians commemorate on May 9 and why it has the world in suspense

Krakow, Poland, May 5 (EFE).- The president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, on Thursday announced aid worth 200 million euros for people who have been displaced by the war in Ukraine.

The EU chief spoke at the International Donors Conference held in Warsaw, organized and attended by Polish prime minister Mateusz Morawiecki and Swedish prime minister Magdalena Andersson, as well as the President of the European Council, Charles Michel, and Ukrainian prime minister Denys Szmyhal.

"The brutality of Russia's aggression is shocking the world," Von der Leyen said, adding that she had witnessed it "with (her) own eyes" when she visited Bucha to "see the mass graves, to see the body bags, to see the scars and wounds in the houses and hospitals that have been shelled.

"It is atrocious. It is a war crime on an everyday basis that Russia is committing," she added.

During her speech, the EC president referred to the sixth package of sanctions against Moscow, unveiled on Wednesday, which includes a total ban on the import of Russian oil.

These measures are "biting deep into the Russian economy," she said. "(Russian president Vladimir) Putin has to pay a price for this aggression."

"We cannot match the bravery and the sacrifice of the Ukrainian people. But we can back you, we can help you with our economic power," von der Leyen said, pointing out that the European Union "has mobilized 3.5 billion euros" and has managed to get "4 billion" to Ukraine.

Morawiecki, meanwhile, said the event showed "that we are not indifferent to the suffering caused by this unjust and brutal war" and emphasized the close relations between Warsaw and Kyiv.

He also called for Ukraine's status as a candidate country for fast-track EU membership and demanded "more funds, more aid and more sanctions against Putin."

"Ukraine needs 12 tons a day of humanitarian aid," the Polish leader emphasized, "and right now it is only receiving 25% of that."

Morawiecki referred to the "more than three million people", mainly women and children, who have crossed the Polish border from Ukraine and welcomed the fact that they have been able to "escape the horror of war" in Poland. EFE

articleSummary.title: EU pledges 200 million euro for Ukraine war displaced

El principal destino inicial de este éxodo es Polonia, donde las llegadas de ciudadanos ucranianos superan los 3,1 millones, seguido de Rumanía (854.000, muchos de ellos tras pasar anteriormente por Moldavia) y Rusia (714.000), según las cifras de ACNUR.

Vladimir Putin has thrown his forces into fierce battles in a steel plant to fully capture Mariupol so he can claim a victory by May 9, the ex-head of the British army said on Thursday.

Russian troops were said to have entered the vast Azovstal steel mill in the besieged port city where around 2,000 Ukrainian fighters, as well as 200 civilians including children, are reported to be inside an underground labyrinth of bunkers and corridors.

Two weeks ago, the Russian president stopped the attack on the plant, the last redoubt of Ukrainian fighters in the largely destroyed city, and ordered his generals to instead surround it so not even a "fly" could get in.

But Lord Dannatt, former head of the British Army, told Sky News on Thursday morning: "They have now come to the conclusion that they have got to have some form of victory to celebrate on Monday.

"It would appear that they have now resumed a direct attack on the steelworks in order to try to snuff out the remaining part of the resistance there so that they can claim on Monday that they have captured Mariupol and therefore they have completed their land corridor from Crimea through the Donbas into Russia proper."

May 9 is a key date in the Russian military calendar as it marks the Nazis' surrender in the Second World War and an annual parade is held through Moscow's Red Square.

Lord Dannatt also believes that Mr Putin may parade Ukrainians prisoners of war through Moscow on Monday.

There are also warnings that he could order a mass mobilisation to turn his "special military operation" in Ukraine into a full-scale war, with an estimated 15,000 Russian troops having already been killed since the invasion started on February 24.

Ukrainian forces said they are fighting "difficult bloody battles" against Russian troops inside the Azovstal steelworks.

"I am proud of my soldiers who are making superhuman efforts to contain the pressure of the enemy... the situation is extremely difficult," Denis Prokopenko, the commander of the Azov regiment, said in a video message posted on Telegram. A senior Russian official earlier denied that troops were storming the plant.

"There is no assault," said Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov.

But the Ukrainian general staff in Kyiv said: "With the support of aircraft, the enemy resumed the offensive in order to take control of the plant... trying to destroy Ukrainian units."

Mariupol mayor Vadym Boychenko said that Russian forces were targeting the plant with artillery, tanks, aircraft, warships and "heavy bombs that pierce concrete three to five meters thick". He added: "Our brave guys are defending this fortress, but it is very difficult."

The United Nations and Red Cross evacuated more than 300 people from Mariupol and other areas this week.

Russia vowed to pause military activity at Azovstal to allow civilians to get out, though previously such offers have collapsed. Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelensky said his military stood ready to support a ceasefire in Mariupol.

"It will take time simply to lift people out of those basements, out of those underground shelters," he said.

To the west of Mariupol, Ukrainian forces made some gains on the border of the southern regions of Kherson and Mykolaiv, where Russian troops were reportedly trying to launch a counter-offensive, and repelled 11 Russian attacks in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions, the military said.

Five people were killed and at least 25 more wounded in shelling of several eastern cities over the past 24 hours, Ukrainian officials said.

Ukrainian foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba accused Russia of "resorting to the missile terrorism tactics in order to spread fear across Ukraine". The invasion has killed at least 221 children, said Ukraine's Prosecutor General's Office.

Pre-candidates for the Planalto criticized former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva's statements to Time magazine, in which he blamed both Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukraine's Volodmir Zelensky for the war in Eastern Europe.

For former governor Ciro Gomes (PDT) - third in the polls for the Presidency of the Republic - "Russia's position has to be condemned." "This is introducing the language of war as a solution to conflicts. And some potential conflicts we need to take care of, because otherwise humanity will go to the violence of a genocide, of mass extinction. See if we can treat the subject with this levity and demagogy of Lula," he said in an interview to CNN.

The former governor of São Paulo, João Doria, pre-candidate for the PSDB, disapproved of the statements. "To say that Zelensky is as guilty as Putin is to exalt authoritarianism and belittle the leader of Ukraine, victim of crimes of a cruel war," he maintained, in a post on Twitter. "Isolates Brazil from the most reasonable positions of the West. Democracy must condemn aggression and conflict. The world wants peace," he added.

Doria's party also expressed itself. "Lula's statements about the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, show that the fact that he presents himself as the candidate of the rescue of Brazilian democracy is a fraud. About Bolsonaro we already know, but the truth is that Lula has always agreed with dictatorial policies," emphasized PSDB.

A petista's disfavor, former minister Sergio Moro (União Brasil) - who still puts himself as available to run for the Plateau - was another who condemned the statements. "Lula, in the Time interview, blames Zelensky, Biden and the European Union for the war in Ukraine. He barely disguises his contempt for Zelensky and his preference for Putin and authoritarian regimes. Is this the democratic way?" he questioned.

Embassy

The Ukrainian embassy in Brazil also reacted to Lula. The diplomatic representation said that the Petista is "misinformed" and therefore will be invited to an audience with the Chargé d'Affaires of Ukraine in Brazil, Mr. Anatoliy Tkach.

"The Embassy of Ukraine has reasons to believe that Mr. Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva is misinformed about the reasons for Russia's war against Ukraine," the diplomatic office said in a statement. "The Embassy plans to formally request an audience of the esteemed former president of Brazil," it adds. According to the diplomatic office, the meeting will be to "clarify Ukraine's position."

Russia invaded Ukraine on February 24, 2022 to allegedly try to prevent the country's rapprochement with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), a representation of the West controlled by the United States. The measure was officially condemned by the United Nations (UN) with Brazil voting in favor, and a series of economic sanctions have already been announced around the world in response.

articleSummary.title: Presidential candidates criticize Lula's statements to Time Magazine

articleContent.content:
Former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (PT) shook up the political world yesterday by winning the cover of the prestigious Time magazine in the United States. The publication calls the PT leader "the most popular leader in Brazil" and says he "seeks to return to the presidency. Lula's supporters flooded the social networks with images from the magazine followed by flattering comments and much provocation to virtual Bolsonarists. But not everything was a party. Once again, statements by the former president provoked reactions and criticism, this time fueling a debate over his position on Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

"Putin should not have invaded Ukraine. But it is not only (Russian President Vladimir) Putin who is guilty, the United States is guilty and the European Union is guilty. What is the reason for the invasion of Ukraine? Is it NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization)? The United States and Europe could have said, 'Ukraine will not join NATO. The problem would be solved," Lula answered to a question about the war. In the sequence, when giving his opinion about the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky, he added: "He is as responsible as Putin, because a war doesn't have only one guilty party.

By leveling invader with invaded, Lula provoked reactions, including among allies of the PT candidacy. The opponents, however, were quick to criticize, including the probable opponents in the October election (read more on page 3).

Among the parties allied to the PT, the recent polemics provoked by Lula's statements and the proportion that they took on caused discomfort. From April onwards, Lula received attacks for saying that abortion is a public health issue, that President Jair Bolsonaro "doesn't like people, he likes policemen", and for defending that voters "map out" addresses of congressmen to hold protests. He also criticized "political correctness", when he complained that he can no longer make jokes about Northeasterners.

For the deputy Heitor Schuch, from PSB - party of the pre-candidate for vice-president, Geraldo Alckmin - "Lula talks a lot, and talks about things that have already passed. "A candidate who talks too much is not elected," he stressed to the Post Office, adding that he does not consider himself personally an ally of the former president.

The PSB's 1st deputy leader in the House, Camilo Capiberibe (AP), believes that the electoral discussion should not be based on polemics, but on what is important to get Brazil out of the crisis it is going through. "(The polemics) mainly benefit Bolsonaro. These are issues that excite the militancy a lot, but that don't translate into anything relevant to the electoral process."

Trending topics

Bolsonaro has taken advantage of the wave of controversial statements of the former president to make political profits and feed his bases on social networks. On the Internet, there was a flurry of criticism from the Bolsonaro wing and former members of the government to the interview on Time. The hashtag #LulaVergonhaDoBrasil was among the most commented subjects on Twitter yesterday, driven by accounts of Bolsonaro supporters. For the federal deputy Capitão Augusto (SP), deputy leader of the PL in the House (PL-SP), the controversial speeches of the former president will help the head of the Executive to overtake Lula in the polls by the end of this month.

"It's so much nonsense that he ends up losing votes and giving way to Bolsonaro. I don't know what is happening with Lula. I don't know if he is underestimating or if he is practically throwing in the towel. But it's unbelievable to talk so much nonsense in a short space of time, and nonsense that impacts voting intentions," he said.

The minister of the Institutional Security Cabinet (GSI) of the Presidency, General Augusto Heleno, said through social networks that Time "belittles the memory and intelligence of good Brazilians. "I regret that it praises and gives space to someone who did so much harm to Brazil and, with his vice, sings the hymn of the Socialist International," he posted.

Congressman Eduardo Bolsonaro (PL-SP) ironized and said that the magazine's editorial choice was a tutorial "on how to lose credibility" by portraying "the biggest crook of a country as your hope." The president's son 02, councilman Carlos Bolsonaro (PL-RJ), republished a thread (serial tweets) of Felipe G. Martins, head of the international advisory office of the Presidency of the Republic, absolved of charges of making Nazi signs in a session in Congress. In the text, the palace adviser claimed that the magazine was "meddling" in Brazilian politics. And cited several companies, people and international actions that, according to him, support Lula.

Noise

The problems in Lula's pre-campaign are pointed out by political scientist Cristiano Noronha, from Arko Advice. He observed that the change in the marketing command is already a perception that there are noises in communication. "Before, Lula was restrained, and Bolsonaro was worn down. But as the campaign gets closer, he is increasing his exposure, and this ends up increasing the chances of error," he stressed. "This will expose the former president, and the person who was thinking of supporting him may end up thinking twice and even change their vote in the direction of Bolsonaro."

According to the specialist, "if Lula continues to make mistakes and the government increasingly continues to adopt measures that can stimulate the economy and improve evaluation indexes, this distance between Bolsonaro and the former president will get closer."

Arthur Wittenberg, professor of public policy at Ibmec, agreed that Lula's recent statements have the potential to take votes away. "There have been at least six statements in recent months. The question is: Has Lula lost his hand or is it a strategy? According to several (voting intention) polls, from January to April, the spacing between Lula and Bolsonaro has dropped," he pointed out.

"Lula's speeches don't deal with the most important issues for the electorate, they are not from the center, they are not propositional on health or the economy. So Lula has been wrong in his speeches, both in the chosen theme and in the form, and has pushed undecided voters to Bolsonaro," he concluded.

Time classifies Lula's candidacy as "Lula's second act," calling him "the most popular leader in Brazil. The report outlines his return to the political arena after spending 580 days in prison as part of the Lava-Jato investigation. It cites, for example, the decision of the Federal Supreme Court (STF) that overturned convictions of the operation and declared the partiality of former judge Sergio Moro in the case. The clashes between President Jair Bolsonaro and the STF were also mentioned by the magazine, which drew a parallel between him and Donald Trump, former US president. "In April, he (Bolsonaro) suggested that the elections could be 'suspended' (he actually spoke of 'suspicion') if 'something abnormal happens,'" an excerpt reads. "If he loses, analysts warn, there is likely to be a Brazilian version of the January 6 riot. If he wins, Brazilian institutions may not endure another four years of his government," it adds.

articleSummary.title: Zelensky is to blame for war, Lula tells Time

articleContent.content:
Lula, who is leading President Bolsonaro in polls, also said Biden and EU are guilty and could have stated Ukraine would not join Nato

Former president of Brazil Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva gestures during a labour day demonstration. Photograph: Rodrigo Paiva/Getty Images

https://www.theguardian.com-Guardian staff and agencies

Brazilian presidential frontrunner Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has said the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskiy, and his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, bear equal responsibility for the war in Ukraine, putting the leftist icon at odds with western powers.

In an interview with Time magazine published on Wednesday, the former president said it was irresponsible for western leaders to celebrate Zelenskiy because they are encouraging war instead of focusing on closed-door negotiations to stop the fighting.

"I see the president of Ukraine , speaking on television, being applauded, getting a standing ovation by all the [European] parliamentarians," Lula told the magazine.

"This guy [Zelenskiy] is as responsible as Putin for the war," he added.

Lula, who is on Time's cover this week, is frontrunner for the October elections when he hopes to deny far-right President Jair Bolsonaro re-election and return to office after the annulment last year of corruption convictions that had put him in jail.

The remarks will probably raise eyebrows in the US and Europe, which are supplying military support to Ukraine and have hit Russia with punishing sanctions over an invasion widely seen in the west as an act of unprovoked Russian aggression.

Lula, 76, said Zelenskiy should have yielded to Russian opposition to Ukraine's moves to join Nato and held negotiations with Putin to avoid a conflict.

Refering to Zelenskiy's rise to fame as an actor and comedian , he added: "We should be having a serious conversation. OK, you were a nice comedian. But let us not make war for you to show up on TV."

The veteran leftist said Biden and European Union leaders failed to do enough to negotiate with Russia in the run-up to its invasion of Ukraine in February.

"The United States has a lot of political clout. And Biden could have avoided war, not incited it," he said. "Biden could have taken a plane to Moscow to talk to Putin. This is the kind of attitude you expect from a leader."

The US and EU could have avoided the invasion by stating that Ukraine would not join Nato, he said.

"Putin shouldn't have invaded Ukraine. But it's not just Putin who is guilty. The US and the EU are also guilty," Lula said

Lula, who leads Bolsonaro in the polls for October's elections, was a key player on the international stage during his two terms as president, building Brazil's diplomatic clout.

Portraying himself as a bridge-builder, he maintained friendly ties with counterparts as disparate as George W Bush of the US and Hugo Chávez of Venezuela or Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran.

CIA Trying To Contact Russians Who Are Against Ukraine War Via Dark Web

Authored by Dave DeCamp via AntiWar.com,

The CIA is trying to contact Russians who are against the war in Ukraine and has offered a secure way to contact the agency . The spy agency wants Russians to communicate with them through a website the CIA set up on the dark web.

"We are providing Russian-language instructions on how to safely contact CIA— via our Dark Web site or a reputable VPN — for those who feel compelled to reach us because of the Russian government's unjust war," a CIA official told CBS News .

The CIA says Russians disaffected by Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine may be trying to get in touch with U.S. intelligence. It wants them to go to the darknet, part of the internet accessible only through tools that provide more anonymity. https://t.co/QOXQz0ZI5P

— The Associated Press (@AP) May 2, 2022

According to CBS , the CIA established a site on the dark web in 2019 and has used it to elicit information from people across the world.

The CIA has releasedinstructions in Russian on how to access the site on Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, and other social media sites.

The site requires users to use the web browser Tor, which encrypts a user's internet activity.The CIA is hoping that Russians, both civilians, and soldiers, will use the site to give information to the US.

An intelligence official told the Associated Press :

"It's not safe to directly engage Americans physically or virtually" in Russia, the official said. "For those people that want to engage with us securely, this is the way to do it."

The CIA's call for Russian contacts could also be related to the US goal of attempting to put pressure on Russian President Vladimir Putin by stirring unrest in Russia.

Sanctions imposed by the US and its allies were meant to turn the Russian populace against Putin , but his approval rating soared to 83% in March, up from 69% in January.

Russian media call him "Darth Vader". U.S. diplomats living in Moscow refer to him as "the Kremlin's gray cardinal" because of his behind-the-scenes influence. He is Igor Sechin, the 61-year-old CEO of state-owned oil giant Rosneft, who has long been considered Vladimir Putin's unofficial second-in-command .

Sechin's unwavering loyalty to Putin over the past two decades has made him extremely wealthy. But how rich? It's hard to say precisely, as Sechin' s fortune is almost as opaque as Putin's , with no paper trail beyond his shares in publicly traded Rosneft.

But based on public records, Russian media reports and yacht valuations provided by VesselsValue, Forbes estimates that Sechin is worth at least $800 million . Or was worth that much until he received sanctions from the European Union on February 28.

Sechin's most valuable assets are two of the world's most valuable yachts : the $511 million 135.636-meter Crescent, which has two helipads, including a retractable hangar, plus a cinema room, beauty salon and swimming pool; and the $134 million 85.64-meter Amore Vero (originally named St. Princess Olga after his second ex-wife Olga Sechina until their divorce in 2017), which has a pool that converts into a helicopter pad.

Both Crescent in Spain and Amore Vero in France were frozen and seized in March . While it is unclear whether Sechin owns Crescent directly or through an associate, VesselsValue identified Sechin as the actual owner of the yacht, as did a Spanish police source cited by Reuters and a yacht industry source who spoke to Forbes. Sechin and his children, Ivan (sanctioned by the U.S. on February 24), Inga and Varvara, also own real estate in the exclusive Moscow suburb of Rublyovka.

According to a report by Russian newspaper Vedomosti, he began building a house on more than 2.8 hectares of land in Rublyovka in 2014, and his children acquired more than 3.23 hectares of land the following year. The properties were purchased for a total of $110 million , according to Vedomosti, which was sued by Sechin for intruding into his ?private life? in its July 2016 article detailing the purchases.

A Russian court forced the newspaper to remove the article for violating Sechin's privacy four months later. The real estate is likely worth close to $100 million today, after taking into account the falling value of the ruble. Sechin also owns a small stake, less than 1%, in Rosneft, worth about $77 million.

Sechin personally declined to comment for this article, but after detailed questions were sent to Rosneft about Sechin's fortune and his rise to power, the company responded that ?as well as the ravings of a madman do not require comment. Their entire content consists of fantasies and delusions divorced from each other, out of touch with reality, as well as wild assumptions, united by maniacal hatred . The authors have clearly been suffering from a variety of phobias for a long time....The authors have clearly been suffering from a variety of phobias for a long time....

How exactly did Sechin get so rich?

One theory is that he has been siphoning off Rosneft' s considerable cash flows : the company, which is the world's second-largest oil producer, had more than $20 billion in net cash in 2020 and $12 billion in 2021.

Sechin] has effectively had control of Rosneft's cash flows for about 20 years? says Vladimir Milov, a Russian opposition politician and economist who served as Russia's deputy energy minister in 2002. ?Rosneft is by far the biggest cash generator in Russia. When you are in a position to dictate where that money goes, you can direct certain flows in this or that direction."

Another theory is that Sechin takes a cut of the profits from Rosneft's energy trading networks , which negotiate the sale and transportation of oil internationally. "Rosneft is heavily involved in international trading networks. It is a way for [Sechin] to get involved relatively easily for his personal enrichment,? says Milov. I'm pretty sure that everyone involved in lucrative deals with Rosneft should be obliged to siphon off a certain percentage of their profits.

? [As an oligarch] you have four ways to make money ,? says Anders Åslund, a Swedish economist who advised Boris Yeltsin on market reforms with Jeffrey Sachs in the early 1990s. "One is asset stripping. The most common is public procurement with bribes. The third is stock manipulation, and the fourth is loans taken and not paid back. In Sechin's case, it's probably a bit of all of them."

Unlike Putin's longtime oligarch friends, such as his former judo training partner Arkady Rotenberg and media mogul Yuri Kovalchuk, Sechin does not appear to have been rewarded with significant ownership in any business . ?Sechin is a servant of Putin,? says Åslund.

That is reflected in his small stake in Rosneft. He behaves less like a modern oligarch, who enriches himself and establishes control over assets, and more like a Soviet dictator of the past, who simply uses things that belong to the company for his personal needs ,? says Milov.

Sechin's political rise

It started in St. Petersburg, where both he and Putin were born and raised. He graduated from Leningrad State University in 1984 with a degree in French and Portuguese and a PhD in economics ; and then worked as a Soviet interpreter in Angola and Mozambique during the Angolan and Mozambican civil wars in the 1980s.

Sechin then returned to Russia to serve as a foreign trade advisor for the St. Petersburg city government in 1988. His time in local government overlapped with Putin , who joined Mayor Anatoly Sobchak's administration as an advisor on international affairs in 1991.

As Putin rose through the ranks, so did Sechin: both men moved to Moscow in 1996 to work in the office of then-President Boris Yeltsin. In the late 1990s, when Putin was head of the Federal Security Service, the successor to the KGB, Sechin held several senior positions in Yeltsin's administration . When Putin took over as acting president in 1999, he made Sechin the deputy head of his administration.

? As Putin moved up the hierarchy, Sechin was there ,? says Thane Gustafson, a Georgetown law professor and expert on Russian energy. Protecting the entrance to his office, managing Putin's life," he says.

The oligarch's business career

Sechin burst onto the business scene in February 2003, when he partnered with then Rosneft chairman Sergey Bogdanchikov in a $623 million deal to take over Severnaya Neft, an oil company with fields in northern Russia. It was an unusual move for state-owned Rosneft, which was left with low-quality assets after oligarchs seized Russia's best oil fields in the 1990s, and the first time a Russian state-owned company acquired a private company.

This was the first time Sechin appeared on the stage. Before that, he was a fairly flexible technocrat," says Milov. His rise was very sudden and absolutely unexpected," he says.

In a televised meeting with Putin that same month, oil tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky, then Russia's richest man, worth $15 billion, publicly argued with the president, accused the Kremlin of corruption and registered his dissatisfaction with the Severnaya Neft deal. Bad move.

Seven months later, Khodorkovsky was arrested on charges of fraud and tax evasion, which led to him losing control of his oil company, Yukos, then one of the world's largest oil producers. He was convicted and spent a decade in prison before being released in 2013. Sechin was appointed chairman of Rosneft's board in July of that year , while remaining Putin's deputy chief of staff.

With Khodorkovsky in prison, Sechin made his move in December 2003, when Rosneft acquired Yukos' core subsidiary Yuganskneftegaz for $9.4 billion, about half its value at the time. In 2005, Yukos sued Rosneft for $11 billion, but went bankrupt the following year. Most of its remaining assets were acquired by Rosneft at a low price in 2007.

The legal battle dragged on for a decade in seven countries, including the US, Russia and the UK. Rosneft finally reached a settlement with Yukos shareholders in 2015. Khodorkovsky told the Sunday Times in 2008 that the cases against him ?were organized by Igor Sechin? as ?an excuse to raid Yukos? Sechin has close ties to Vladimir Ustinov, the prosecutor general who orchestrated the Yukos raid : his daughter, Inga, is married to Ustinov's son, Dmitry.

In May 2012, Sechin left his post as Putin's deputy prime minister and became CEO of Rosneft . Seven months later, Rosneft bought Russian oil company TNK-BP for $55 billion. The deal meant huge payouts for at least half a dozen billionaires who were investors in TNK-BP, including Mikhail Fridman, Viktor Vekselberg and Leonard Blavatnik. It also left BP with a 19.75% stake in Rosneft, which it still owns today, although the firm announced on February 27 that it would "exit its shareholding". Potential buyers include state-owned oil companies in China, India and Qatar, and even Rosneft itself.

The multibillion-dollar expenditure

As Rosneft's assets grew, so did Sechin's ability to spend big . In 2012, he bought the St. Princess Olga (renamed Amore Vero, or ?true love?, after Sechin divorced Olga), which was delivered in 2013. He bought Crescent that same year, but the massive superyacht took five years to build. In 2014 and 2015, he spent $110 million on his property outside Moscow.

Sechin certainly didn't make enough money in his day job to fund those lavish purchases. He earned as much as $50 million in 2013, making him the highest-paid CEO in the country, according to Forbes Russia . The famous lawsuit Sechin sued Forbes Russia for defamation in May 2014 and a Russian court ruled three months later that the article should be removed because it created a ?negative image? of Sechin. The only time Rosneft publicly disclosed its rules for Sechin's compensation was in 2015, a month after Putin said on his annual TV show that the heads of state-owned companies should report their income. At the time, Forbes Russia estimated that Sechin earned $17.5 million in 2014.

There were also subsequent settlements. Rosneft paid $5.2 billion for a majority stake in oil producer Bashneft in 2016 , buying it from the Russian government, which had seized it from Russian billionaire Vladimir Yevtushenkov in October 2014 after he was arrested on money laundering charges linked to his own acquisition of Bashneft. He was released that December and the charges were later dropped.

According to Khodorkovsky, Sechin was the mastermind behind the expropriation of Bashneft, following a playbook similar to the one he used against Yukos . ?This is the same Igor [Sechin] who has not gotten smarter in 11 years and may have gotten even greedier,? he told Russian daily Vedomosti in 2014. Khodorkovsky did not respond to a request for comment from Forbes at the time of publication.

The financial highway linking Sechin and Putin runs in both directions . Rosneft contributed money to build the ?Putin Palace, an opulent 57,912-square-meter property near the resort town of Gelendzhik on the Black Sea coast. According to the E.U. sanctions, ?Rosneft participated in the financing of the vineyards of the palace complex near Gelendzhik, which is considered to be used personally by President Putin? A 2021 investigation by Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation claims that Putin owns the mansion, which cost approximately $1 billion to build. Putin has denied that he owns it; his childhood friend and sanctioned oligarch Arkady Rotenberg says it belongs to him.

The multiple sanctions

As for Sechin' s personal wealth , he was first sanctioned by the United States in 2014 , following Russia's annexation of Crimea. But it was not until March 2022, weeks after the European Union imposed sanctions on him, that French and Spanish authorities targeted his two superyachts.

The first blow came on March 3, when French Customs formally seized Amore Vero in the port of La Ciotat on the French Riviera. The press release announcing the seizure identified Sechin as the beneficial owner of the yacht. Two weeks later, on March 16, Spanish authorities froze Crescent in Tarragona, about 60 miles south of Barcelona , while they worked to confirm ownership of the yacht.

Most yachts owned by oligarchs are held through complex chains of offshore holding companies , and Sechin's are no different. Crescent's registered owner is Densiarly Enterprises Ltd / Trident Trust Co (Cayman), based in the Cayman Islands, and Amore Vero is registered to Kazimo Trade & Invest Ltd, based in the Virgin Islands.British.

Both vessels are managed by Monaco-based Imperial Yachts , a company that one yachting industry source called "Putin's people when it comes to yachts." An Imperial spokesperson told Forbes that Sechin is not the beneficial owner of Crescent or Amore Vero, but confirmed that the firm has managed Amore Vero since 2018, when it was ?purchased by its current owner? (Neither Forbes nor VesselsValue could find evidence that Amore Vero was sold in 2018 or that ownership was transferred.)

? [Imperial] is the most secretive operation in the industry because of its ties to the Russians in power ," the yacht industry source told Forbes. If you're in Putin's inner circle, you buy through Imperial. Imperial also built the 139.9-meter, $700 million Scheherazade, which was recently linked to Vladimir Putin by Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation. An Imperial spokesman told Forbes that the company acted as Scheherazade's construction manager but does not currently manage the yacht. "Imperial Yachts has no clients who are sanctioned individuals or entities," they added.

There has been speculation that Sechin controls the assets through his associates, including former Rosneft CEO Eduard Khudainatov . Khudainatov was Rosneft's CEO while Sechin served as Putin's deputy prime minister, before Sechin took over as CEO in 2012. After a brief stint as deputy chairman of Rosneft, Khudainatov left Rosneft in 2013 to launch his own oil company, Independent Oil Company. "Many people consider Khudainatov to be one of Sechin's portfolios," Milov says.

According to VesselsValue, Khudainatov is the owner of the 106.07-meter, $245 million yacht Amadea , which is registered in the Cayman Islands and held through Cayman-based Millemarin Investments Ltd. Amadea is also managed by Imperial, and Khudainatov has also been linked to the Scheherazade as a possible front man for Putin. Amadea is currently tied up in Lautoka, Fiji, where it is subject to a restraining order preventing it from leaving the country pending a U.S. seizure order.

While Sechin can no longer access his superyachts, he remains the owner of Crescent and Amore Vero . ?There is no actual transfer of ownership? when a yacht is frozen or seized, says Benjamin Maltby, a partner at London-based law firm Keystone Law who focuses on superyachts.

Despite the sanctions, Sechin appears to have found a way to continue paying for Amore Vero's maintenance at La Ciotat Shipyard, where the vessel was impounded while undergoing repairs . La Ciotat communications officer Alice Boisseau told Forbes that La Ciotat is ?receiving payments as usual? and that the yacht is still docked at the shipyard.

Receiving payments from Sechin, even if routed through offshore companies and third parties, could be a sanctions violation , according to Maltby. Boisseau told Forbes that ?La Ciotat Shipyards will maintain full compliance with the sanctions under the supervision of French Customs? A French Customs spokesman declined to comment.

As sanctions and seizures pile up, Sechin appears to be in hiding in Russia, away from his luxury yachts . His last public appearance outside the country was at an economic forum in Verona, Italy, in October. On the day Russia invaded Ukraine, he attended a meeting with Putin and other Russian business leaders at the Kremlin. A Boeing 737-700 commercial aircraft registered in Austria with the tail number OE-IRF, operated by Rosneft and reportedly used by Sechin's family friends for a vacation in the Maldives in 2016, made several flights between Moscow and Frankfurt, St. Petersburg and Dubai in the two months before the war. His last flight was on February 8, when he flew from Moscow to Frankfurt and back in eight hours. Other than that, he has been invisible.

articleSummary.title: The murky fortunes of Igor Sechin, the Kremlin's Darth Vader

On March 16, the Russian army advanced on Chernihiv, Bucha and Irpin, Ukraine – firing steel-cased ammunition from the military's AK rifles. 

On the other side of the globe, a cargo ship carrying the same type of ammo from St. Petersburg docked in Philadelphia. A container with pallets of shrink-wrapped boxes slowly made its way to warehouses in Florida, South Carolina and Ohio and onto store shelves nationwide. 

All Russian ammo was banned for import to the U.S. as of Sept. 7, 2021, but the cheap 7.62 x 39 mm bullets – favored by many Americans for target practice with semiautomatic rifles – kept flowing because of a State Department loophole allowing existing and pending import permits to stand. Russian brands such as Wolf, TulAmmo and Barnaul are easy to find at gun shops and U.S.-based online retailers.

The sanctions and the grandfathered Russian imports have split the top firearm lobbies and gun owners: Some take a hard-line Second Amendment view, some fall on the side of democratic support for Ukraine, some seem to be torn between the two.

The Biden administration announced the ban in August 2021 in reaction to the poisoning of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny the year before. The ban also came as intelligence agencies reported Russia amassing 100,000 troops at the Ukrainian border. 

Once President Vladimir Putin attacked Ukraine in February, U.S. sanctions were extended to virtually every international piece of the Russian banking system.

Since 2014, when Russia invaded Crimea, the Treasury Department has sanctioned oligarchs close to Putin and arms manufacturers close to the government. TulAmmo is among the popular brands under scrutiny for purported ties to the Russian defense conglomerate Rostec, which has been sanctioned, and oligarchs such as Putin ally Igor Rotenberg.

A USA TODAY analysis of bills of lading data shows shipments from seven Russian munitions plants have arrived in the USA since September through 13 American ammunition importers. That totaled 8,000 metric tons – more than 400 million rounds – almost on pace with all of 2021.

The allure is obvious: the ammunition costs a fraction of domestic-made versions. Online retailers sell the Russian-made AK rounds for 34 cents apiece – whereas Texas-loaded brass rounds sell for close to a dollar.

Gun rights lobby is conflicted

The National Rifle Association decried the sanctions in September as an attack on the Second Amendment. But it broke with its traditional policy of broadly advocating for access to all foreign ammunition in a statement to USA TODAY.

"During an international conflict with Russian aggression at the center, the NRA – along with almost all American companies – is not prioritizing the protection of access to Russian goods," spokeswoman Amy Hunter said.

Another gun rights group, Gun Owners of America, is fighting the "Biden Ammo Ban," which it said will do little to crimp the Russian export economy, particularly compared with the massive energy exports flowing in pipelines to Europe and elsewhere. The group accused the president of hating gun owners.

Actions by the National Shooting Sports Foundation, which represents gun shops, manufacturers and importers, highlight the dichotomies. The group sent lobbyists to Capitol Hill last year to monitor the looming sanctions. It sought to help importers understand rules around "Form 6" permits to import Russian ammunition.

A bulletin sent to NSSF members Aug. 30 read, "It is NSSF's understanding that approved Form 6's will not be rescinded and Form 6's already submitted will be approved until Sept. 7." Those permits are good for two years.

Regulators declined to divulge how many permits were approved just before the deadline. Barnaul importer Charles Brown said on the floor of the NSSF annual trade show in January that when he heard the sanctions were coming, he "hammered in" a bevy of permit applications under the deadline.

Months later, after Russian troops flooded into Ukraine, the NSSF helped its members donate American-made brass ammunition to the Ukrainians. It connected ammunition companies with U.S. ammunition regulators at the Commerce Department and provided addresses for shipping to the Ukrainian military.

It reaped the benefits of public relations attention for that move, including a feature in Firearms News magazine in which NSSF spokesman Mark Oliva said his industry had answered Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's "clarion call: 'The fight is here; I need ammunition, not a ride.' "

Russian plants have military ties , obscure financing

Despite the sanctions responding to the Crimea invasion in 2014, U.S. importers maintained lucrative business contracts with manufacturers as long as they steered clear of Treasury's sanction list, which identifies off-limits companies.

International business experts called into question the true Russian owners and government ties of many ammunition manufacturers because of the country's opaque reporting requirements. Gun safety advocates said the presence of Russian manufacturers at trade shows such as the massive SHOT Show in Las Vegas prove the cozy industry ties.

"Too many American firearms companies will do anything to make a few extra bucks, even if that means continuing to do business with a Russian defense industry that has been fueling a tragedy in Ukraine since Putin invaded Crimea in 2014," said John Feinblatt, president of Everytown for Gun Safety.

Many of the brands, including Barnaul, market their product to appear like surplus ammo from the Soviet era, even though it is newly manufactured. Barnaul sells olive drab "spam cans" of 700-round packages sealed in tin canisters "ideal for long term airtight storage" and labeled in Russian Cyrillic lettering.

When the Conflict Armament Research group in the U.K. analyzed nearly 5,000 rounds of small-arms ammunition recovered in Ukraine since 2014 in battle-torn Donetsk and Luhansk, it found a majority of those rounds were produced in five Russian plants. Barnaul Cartridge Plant was the No. 1 provider; Tula and Vympel also were named.

An importer in Florida received its shipments of ammo in February from the Amursk Cartridge Plant – Vympel, according to shipping records analyzed by USA TODAY. On its website, the Amursk factory boasts it is a government-backed facility named strategically important by the Russian Federation and a "key element of the country's defense system in terms of providing the army with the most modern samples of ammunition."

Same ammo fired on the battlefield for sale here

Russian-manufactured ammunition has been sold at an increasing rate since 2014, according to Small Arms Analytics, which analyzes trade data. Importers brought in 765 million units – empty and filled cartridges – of technically legal Russian munitions in 2020 and 862 million through the end of last year.

Russia has been by far the largest supplier of imported rounds to the USA and by some industry estimates has provided up to 10% of all ammunition here. Americans buy roughly 10 billion rounds of ammunition annually, according to the NSSF. 

U.S. import data due out in May will begin to show the impacts of the sanctions on the ammunition market. Forecasters at Small Arms Analytics anticipate the data will show that other Eastern European countries such as the Czech Republic and Serbia increased their output to fill the void.

That leaves American gun owners and gun store operators options in deciding whether to continue snapping up the cheap ammunition from Russia.

Shooters should opt to pay a little more to avoid supporting Russia, said Bill Brown, an importer for Reno-based Battle Born Munitions. He said he sold off his inventory, left permits unfilled and cut off Russian contracts.

"Why are you supporting the Russian war machine? Do you feel comfortable selling Russian-made military ammunition that's fueling and funding the atrocities in Ukraine?" Brown said. "When you pay your 30 cents for a round, 28 of it goes back to Mother Russia. There's no way you can contest that."

NSSF spokesman Oliva disagrees, contending that any ammunition on store shelves was bought and paid for months before Russia became a global pariah. 

"We want our members to stay in business, but companies can make their own value-based decisions, and that's evident by the companies making donations to Ukraine," Oliva said in an interview. "We focus on what the law says and don't take a position on the sanctions."

Gun enthusiasts are conflicted, said Brandon Herrera, a Texas-based YouTube expert on AK firearms with nearly 2 million subscribers. He said he worries the sanctions will do more harm to American consumers than Putin.

"I think a lot of the gun community is with Ukraine and against the occupation," Herrera said, noting the war has played out in his video channel's comments section between global supporters of Russia and of Ukraine.

"If you're an average person deciding not to buy this ammo and you're out to protest Russia," he said, "you need to remember the difference between Russian citizens and the actions of Putin."

Brandon Herrera, a Texas-based YouTube expert on AK firearms, posted this YouTube video analyzing the ban on Russian ammunition when the sanctions were announced in August.

Importers face sanctions , banking freeze, duty

The complex and shifting sanction environment has made business tough for importers that specialize in Russian ammunition, said Charles Brown, the supplier who said he "hammered in" his permit applications to beat the sanctions. Brown owns Ohio-based MKS Supply, a U.S. supplier of Barnaul ammunition.

Records show MKS has imported 650 tons of Russian ammunition since September – about 9% of the total imported. The State Department's two-year loophole for permit holders means Brown could legally continue importing Russian ammunition – if he could clear all the banking, shipping and economic hurdles. 

He said the U.S. government's blocks on Russian banking mean he could not wire money for his new orders. The Biden administration's revocation of "most-favored nation" status for Russia added an extra duty on many imports – 30% for things like ammunition, plywood and caviar.

More: Biden's new sanctions on Russia could hit grain, fertilizer, seafood and luxury goods

His March shipment may have been his last, Brown said.

"It's complicated," he said. "Personally, yeah, we're resistant to the sanctions, it affects our business. But now you get into deeper questions: Should Russia be sanctioned? How do you feel about the war? We're a business that imports from Russia, but everything happening in Ukraine is vile and disgusting."

Brown's bottom line is that consumers should be free to make their own purchasing decisions.

"That's what makes us Americans, it's a personal choice and some would be happy to purchase from a sanctioned company and some may not," he said. "A lot of these sanctions are hurting U.S. companies more than the Russians."

Contributing: Brett Murphy

Nick Penzenstadler is a reporter on the USA TODAY investigations team. Contact him at npenz@usatoday.com or @npenzenstadler, or on Signal at (720) 507-5273.
